description: Variant of clew (“a ball of thread or yarn”), from Middle English clewe, from Old English clīewen (“ball”), from Proto-West Germanic *kliuwīn, from Proto-Germanic *kliuwīną, *klewô (“ball, bale”), from Proto-Indo-European *glew- (“to amass, conglomerate; clump, ball, bale”). Sense evolution with reference to the one which the mythical Theseus used to guide him out of the Minotaur's labyrinth. More at clew.

entries.meaning: (now rare) A strand of yarn etc. as used to guide one through a labyrinth; something which points the way, a guide.
Information which may lead one to a certain point or conclusion.
examples: Give me a clue because the question is too vague.

entries.meaning: An object or a kind of indication which may be used as evidence.
examples: The detectives were looking for some clues at the scene of the crime.

entries.meaning: Insight or understanding ("to have a clue [about]" or "to have clue". See have a clue, clue stick)
examples: I had little clue that I was being carefully monitored by the CCTV.

verbs.description: clue (third-person singular simple present clues, present participle cluing or clueing, simple past and past participle clued)

examples: The crossword compiler wasn't sure how to clue the word "should".

entries.meaning: To provide someone with information which he or she lacks (often used with "in" or "up").
examples: Smith, clue Jones in on what's been happening.
You need to clue me what to do, I have no idea.
